title: cata-list
description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

articles.title: Physicists 3D Print a Boat That Could Sail Down a Human Hair
articles.description: Researchers at Leiden University have 3D printed the smallest boat in the world: a 30-micrometer copy of Benchy the tug boat, a well-known 3D printer test object. This boat is so small, it could float down the interior of a human hair.

articles.title: Scientists Discover the First Room-Temperature Superconductor
articles.description: Physicists finally achieved the long-sought goal, but there's a catch: Their compound requires crushing pressures to keep from falling apart.

articles.title: Reflections on Solzhenitsyn's Harvard Address
articles.description: In his 1978 Harvard commencement address, A World Split Apart, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, a fierce enemy of the Soviet system, delivered a forceful and insightful critique of the West, a society which…

articles.title: My Week With the Baying Antifa Mob
articles.description: In the days when you could still watch a nature documentary without feeling as if you were sitting through a politics lecture I saw footage of a pack of smaller predators taking down an elephant. At the time I remember thinking: 'Why don't you keep running? Why don't you knock t…

articles.title: What Divides Us Is Class, Not Race
articles.description: Black lives matter. It's become a rallying cry for those seeking social and racial justice. These three words express the idea, symbolized by the death of George Floyd, that race defines the fault …

articles.title: Cancel Culture Has Captured Campus
articles.description: The philosophical origins of the Woke ideology are analysed in two new books

articles.title: Russians Who Pose Election Threat Have Hacked Nuclear Plants and Power Grid
articles.description: The hacking group, Energetic Bear, is among Russia's stealthiest. It appears to be casting a wide net to find useful targets ahead of the election, experts said.

articles.title: Aliens From These Worlds Could Be Watching Us Right Now
articles.description: Astronomers have catalogued more than 3,000 exoplanets using a fairly basic detection technique known as the transit method. What if aliens are using the same technique to spy on us?

articles.title: Print These Electronic Circuits Directly Onto Skin
articles.description: Room-temperature sintering enables skin sensors for vital signs.

articles.title: Scientists Found a New Way to Break Down the Most Common Plastic
articles.description: The plastics industry produces over 88 million tons of polyethylene, the most common plastic in the world. Scientists have found a new way to upcycle it, according to a study published in Science. It could help deal with the growing plastic pollution crisis.

articles.title: The Importance of Blasphemy
articles.description: Anyone who thought the age of plague might have banished the specter of religious fanaticism was disabused last week when a middle school teacher in a Paris suburb was beheaded by an Islamist fanat…

articles.title: Philosophy Is Being Hijacked by Woke Twitter Mobs
articles.description: Philosophers tend to be highly influenced by their environment, and can often be found rationalizing instead of critically examining the conventional views of the people around them. But if anythin…

articles.description: FBI and senators all beg Americans: please do not fall for shady disinformation.

articles.title: Former Google CEO Calls Social Networks 'Amplifiers for Idiots'
articles.description: Former Google Chief Executive Officer Eric Schmidt said the 'excesses' of social media are likely to result in greater regulation of internet platforms in the coming years.

articles.title: DOJ Lets Opioid Ghouls at Purdue Pharma Off With a Slap on the Wrist
articles.description: The 'Empire of Pain' and the family that profited from it scored a sick joke of a settlement with the Department of Justice on Wednesday, evading accountability for their role in the nationwide opioid epidemic.

articles.title: Iran and Russia Obtained US Voter Registration Data, Officials Say
articles.description: 'Iran and Russia have taken specific actions to influence public opinion relating to our election.'

articles.title: Google Paid Apple Billions to Dominate Search on iPhones, Justice Department Says
articles.description: An agreement worth up to $12 billion made Google the de facto choice for online search on millions of iPhones. Justice officials say the deal may be anticompetitive under U.S. law.

articles.title: DOJ Antitrust Lawsuit Aims at the Heart of Google's $1 Trillion Business
articles.description: After a 16-month investigation, the Department of Justice and 11 states filed an antitrust lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, arguing that the company's search app hurts search competition and disproportionately funnels traffic to Google's ad business.

articles.title: Got Any Signal Up Here? Nokia to Build Mobile Network on the Moon
articles.description: Struggling to get a phone signal at home on planet Earth? Perhaps you'll have better luck on the moon.

articles.title: Babies May Be Drinking Millions of Microplastic Particles a Day
articles.description: Scientists discover that baby bottles shed up to 16 million bits of plastic per liter of fluid. What that means for infants' health, no one can yet say.

articles.title: US Indicts Sandworm, Russia's Most Destructive Cyberwar Unit
articles.description: The Department of Justice has named and charged six men for allegedly carrying out many of the most costly cyberattacks in history.

articles.title: Japan Going Ahead With Plan to Dump Radioactive Water Into the Sea
articles.description: It appears Japan is ready to proceed with dumping over 1 million tons of contaminated water from the destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant into the ocean.

articles.title: COVID-19 Cases Top 8 Million in the US
articles.description: More than one out of every 50 people in the US is known to have or have had COVID-19.

articles.title: Methane Emissions Are Up Even Though Natural Gas Demand Is Down
articles.description: New satellite images show that the world's number of large methane hotspots increased by nearly a third in the first eight months 2020, despite industry pledges to reduce greenhouse gas pollution and tanking fuel demand tied to the pandemic.

articles.title: Fracking Is Elevating Levels of Radioactivity Downwind
articles.description: Hydraulic fracturing has been a big topic of the upcoming presidential election. Biden has refused to ban it, Trump has said he'll expand it hugely. But a new Harvard study suggests that the drilling practice is even more dangerous than we previously thought.

articles.title: The Destruction of the Great Barrier Reef Is Clearer Than Ever
articles.description: Coral populations on the Great Barrier Reef have declined precipitously in the past 20 years.

articles.description: It … let's just say it would not be good. Here, let's do the math.

articles.description: Every type of coral has declined since 1995 because of climate change, an Australian study finds.

articles.description: The structure of black phosphorus naturally makes channels to let lithium in.

articles.description: Airliners carry a variety of computer systems that could become vulnerable to hackers and U.S. regulators haven't imposed adequate counter measures, a government watchdog report concluded.

articles.description: The IRS used smartphone location data from a contractor to try to track Americans without a warrant.

articles.title: Why Humanity Destroyed Itself
articles.description: The real reason we may destroy ourselves isn't really to do with politics or economics or even warfare. It has to do with our minds.

articles.title: California Fires Set Bleak Record as 4m Acres Destroyed
articles.description: Four million figure double the previous record for most land burned as officials warn that season is 'far from over and fire potential remains high'

articles.title: Greenland Melting Fastest Any Time in Last 12,000 Years
articles.description: Researchers determined that Greenland is on track to lose more ice this century than during any of the previous 120 centuries. Christopher Intagliata reports.

articles.title: Trump Likely Had the Virus During the Debate, According to Medical Experts

articles.title: 90 Percent of Coronavirus Patients Experience Side Effects After Recovery, Study Finds
articles.description: An online survey of 965 recovered COVID-19 patients found 9 in 10 reported experiencing symptoms such as fatigue, loss of taste and smell and psychological issues.

articles.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is poised to pay close to $1 billion to resolve market manipulation investigations by U.S. authorities into its trading of metals futures and Treasury securities, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.

articles.title: Scientists May Have Found a Material for Building on Mars

articles.title: Australia Says World Needs to Know Origins of COVID-19
articles.description: The world's nations must do all they can to understand the origins of COVID-19, Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Saturday, comments that could worsen tensions with China.

articles.title: Crows Possess Higher Intelligence Long Thought Primarily Human
articles.description: A second study looked in unprecedented detail at the brains of pigeons and barn owls, finding hints to the basis of their intelligence.

articles.description: Former director Tim Kendall said Facebook 'took a page from Big Tobacco's playbook, working to make our offering addictive at the outset.'

articles.description: A Rand report finds the median salary could have been $102,000, instead of $50,000, for a full-time worker if wages and GDP grew at the same rate.

articles.title: Facebook Accused of Watching Instagram Users Through Cameras
articles.description: Facebook Inc. is again being sued for allegedly spying on Instagram users, this time through the unauthorized use of their mobile phone cameras.The lawsuit springs from media reports in July that the photo-sharing app appeared to be accessing iPhone cameras even when they weren’t actively being used.Facebook denied the reports and blamed a bug, which it said it was correcting, for triggering what it described as false notifications that Instagram was accessing iPhone cameras.

articles.title: Antarctic Glaciers Are Growing Unstable Above and Below Water
articles.description: New studies show fractures on surface ice and warm seawater melting the ice from underneath. That's a harbinger of a coming collapse—and sea level rise.

articles.description: The government is urged to do more to get people to wear reusable, washable face coverings.
